Hal Mumme: New OC "a great move for Kentucky"

Hal Mumme, Air Raid guru, has been a fan of Kentucky's new coordinator for years

Hal Mumme: New OC "a great move for Kentucky"

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 8:48 p.m. EST December 18, 2014

Former Kentucky coach Hal Mumme is a big fan (and former boss) of new Cats offensive coordinator Shannon Dawson.(Photo: Rogelio V. Solis, AP)

83 CONNECT 31 TWEETLINKEDIN 2 COMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. The first time new University of Kentucky offensive coordinator Shannon Dawson met Hal Mumme, the former was begging for a job a dozen years ago. The latter, the man who popularized the "Air Raid" offense with the Wildcats in the late 1990s, was doing all he could to scare off the poor kid.

"I say, 'Look, I'm not going to pay you for six months and you gotta do all the video.' I came up with all the bad jobs I could think of," Mumme remembers. "I was really trying to run him off, but he kept sitting there and nodding his head. 'Yes, sir. Yes, sir. Yes, sir.'

"So I tell him again I'm not going to pay him for six months. He says, 'I'll take the job.' "

The job, as advertised, wasn't much.

After leaving Lexington in early 2001 amid an NCAA investigation, followed by a brief period of exile, Mumme had resurfaced with a new challenge in 2002: rebooting a Southeastern Louisiana football program that had been dormant for nearly two decades.

At some point in the more than 400 days between the time Mumme took that job and the Lions' first game, friend and Air Raid disciple Dana Holgorsen then at Texas Tech and now the head coach at West Virginia called to say keep an eye out for Dawson.

MORE UK: Source: UK to hire WVU's Dawson as coordinator

He'd played wide receiver for Holgorsen at Division II Wingate and was a bright young football mind, just a year out of college, looking to break into the business and willing to work hard for little (or no) pay. But Mumme was only half listening. He jotted the name down on a scrap of paper, which disappeared on his desk almost immediately.

"We got one phone, one ball, one helmet, one legal pad, one box of staples. We had nothing, so I'm real busy hustling money and hustling players and everything you've got to do to get a program started," Mumme said. "I don't really think much about it. About a month goes by and this guy shows up at my door. The young lady working for me in the office says, 'Rick Dawson's son is here to see you.' "

Rick was a former football player with a strong desire to see the Southeastern Louisiana program reborn and enough money to help make that happen. In other words, Mumme was obliged to humor his boy whether he liked it or not. (He didn't.)

"That was like the last thing in the world that I wanted to hear," Mumme said, "that I had to hire a booster's son. So I kind of ignored it."

Even at Shannon Dawson's impromptu interview, Mumme didn't make the connection that he was the same guy Holgorsen had been hawking.

"I just think it's the booster's son," he said. "So I grill the guy."

But Dawson was so unfazed and seemed so sharp that Mumme threw him a bone. He hired him as an offensive quality control coach. "Unglamorous" doesn't do that job justice.

"I put this guy through hell for six months," Mumme said. Then Holgorsen called again. "He says, 'Hey, I was really glad to see you hired Shannon. How's he doing?' It's like on 'Beavis and Butt-Head,' when they used to have that little light bulb above Beavis' head and all the sudden it would light up, you know? 'Oh, hell, that's the guy Dana recommended and I've been trying to run him off!' "

So Dawson made it to the program's first game as a start-up program in 2003, but he almost didn't get much further. That opener was pressure-packed. A clock outside Mumme's office had been counting down to the return of football for more than a year. There had been two pep rallies.

"It was like a bowl game," Mumme said, and they were losing it in the fourth quarter.

Hal Mumme, the creator of the Air Raid offense, was named the new head football coach at Belhaven University. (Video by Courtney Cronin/The Clarion-Ledger).

Nothing if not bold, Dawson approached his boss.

"He's supposed to just be kind of standing on the sideline watching me call plays," Mumme said, "and he goes, 'You know, Coach, if we ran Fox right here' that was the name of one of our plays 'we'd probably score.' So I start to chew him out for having the audacity to try to call a play in that most heated moment, and then I said, 'This guy's pretty smart. I should probably listen to him.'

"I did, and we drew up the play, threw a touchdown pass on it and won the game. I've been a Shannon Dawson fan ever since then."

Dawson was promoted to running backs coach the next season, then Mumme took him along to New Mexico State in 2005. His career has been a swift, steady ascent since. He became offensive coordinator at Division III Millsaps in 2006, took the same job at Stephen F. Austin in 2008 and reunited with Holgorsen at West Virginia in 2011.

Dawson, now 37, has made the "Air Raid" fly at every stop. Millsaps ranked fifth nationally in total offense his second season there. Stephen F. Austin led the nation in passing his last two years. The Mountaineers ranked ninth in passing and 11th in total offense this season with Dawson as offensive coordinator.

MORE UK: UK's Neal Brown announced as Troy head coach

"He's really a brilliant guy," Mumme said. "This is a great move for Kentucky."

It's also an important move for Dawson, who most considered a coordinator in title only at West Virginia. Holgorsen, who confirmed Dawson's departure Thursday, still had the final say in play selection. So did Mumme back when a guy by the name of Mike Leach was his offensive coordinator at Kentucky.

Leach's career took off when he struck out on his own. He became a star head coach at Texas Tech just one year after leaving UK to work for a defensive coach, Bob Stoops, at Oklahoma. Little brother Mark Stoops, another former defensive coordinator, is the Cats head coach who just hired Dawson.

"It's really good for him," Mumme said. "Mike was always trying to get head-coaching jobs but they'd always ask him, 'Who really calls the plays?' This will give Shannon the same opportunity Leach had when he went to OU. And he'll be great at it. I have no doubt about that. He always has been."

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
